title: Cookbook
text:
Welcome to my flavorful corner of the internet! As someone who delights in experimenting with new recipes, I’ve found that generative AI brings a novel twist to the kitchen. By providing innovative and unique combinations, it keeps my culinary journey fresh. This website serves as both a repository for the dishes I’ve tried and a space for me to reflect on what worked and what did not.
Inspired by the delectable artistry of Yotam Ottolenghi, I often challenge the generative AI to reimagine his recipes with alternative ingredients, ensuring that my pantry’s constraints never dull my taste buds. I invite you to explore this collection of recipes, and perhaps discover your own flavorful inspiration along the way.

title: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
text:
Recipe for Mother’s day, May 14, 2023.






Prompt: “Capture the essence of Gustave Caillebotte’s style in a still life painting, showcasing a platter of porter beer-braised beef, a dish of Ottolenghi-inspired roast potatoes, and a bowl of fresh broccoli, peas, and mixed greens salad with pomegranate arils”

title: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
section: Main Course: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
text:
Main Course: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
Ingredients:

1.5kg beef roast (such as topside or rib-eye)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
3 tbsp olive oil
1.2kg small waxy potatoes, peeled and halved
2 tbsp za’atar
1 tbsp sumac
Zest of 1 lemon
3 tbsp chopped fresh parsley
2 bottles (24 oz) porter beer
3 celery stalks, chopped
2 onions, chopped
3 carrots, chopped

For the gravy:

Drippings from the beef
2 tbsp all-purpose flour
1 cup beef broth
Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:

Season the beef roast generously with salt and pepper. Heat 2 tbsp of olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Sear the beef on all sides until browned, about 3-4 minutes per side.
Add the porter beer to the pot, followed by the chopped celery, onions, and carrots. The beer should cover the beef roast. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and cover the pot. Let it simmer for 2.5 to 3 hours, or until the beef is fork-tender.
Preheat the oven to 200°C (400°F).
Prepare the roast potatoes. In a large bowl, toss the potatoes with the remaining 1 tbsp of olive oil, za’atar, sumac, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Spread the potatoes in a single layer on a baking sheet and roast for 35-40 minutes, or until golden and crispy, turning them halfway through cooking.
Remove the beef from the pot and place it on a cutting board. Tent with foil, and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
While the beef is resting, prepare the gravy. Strain the cooking liquid from the pot into a bowl, reserving the vegetables. Skim off any fat from the surface of the liquid.
In the same pot, heat 2 tbsp of the beef drippings over medium heat. Whisk in the flour and cook, stirring constantly, for 1-2 minutes. Slowly whisk in the reserved cooking liquid and beef broth. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer until the gravy has thickened, about 5-10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
To serve, slice the beef roast and arrange on a platter with the roasted potatoes and reserved vegetables. Sprinkle the potatoes with lemon zest and chopped parsley. Serve the gravy alongside the beef.

section: Broccoli, Peas, and Mixed Greens Salad with Pomegranate Arils
text:
Broccoli, Peas, and Mixed Greens Salad with Pomegranate Arils
Ingredients:

1 large head of broccoli, cut into small florets
1 cup frozen peas, thawed
4 cups mixed greens (such as spinach, arugula, and baby kale)
1 cup pomegranate arils
1/4 cup crumbled feta cheese (optional)

For the dressing:

3 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil
2 tbsp freshly squeezed lemon juice
1 tbsp honey
1 small garlic clove, minced
Salt and freshly ground black pepper, to taste

Instructions:

Microwave the peas in a bowl of water, up to the level of covering the peas, for 8-12 minutes. Drain water and let cool.
Bring a pot of salted water to a boil. Add the broccoli florets and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until they’re bright green and slightly tender. Drain the broccoli and immediately transfer it to a bowl of ice water to stop the cooking process. Let the broccoli sit in the ice water for a minute and then drain.
In a large salad bowl, combine the blanched broccoli, cooked peas, mixed greens, and pomegranate arils. If desired, add crumbled feta cheese for extra flavor and texture.
Prepare the dressing by whisking together the extra-virgin olive oil, lemon juice, honey, minced garlic, salt, and pepper in a small bowl.
Drizzle the dressing over the salad and toss to combine. Serve the salad alongside the porter beer-braised beef and Ottolenghi-inspired roast potatoes. Enjoy!

title: Roasted Cauliflower and Chickpea Salad
text:
Prepared for a soirée on the 14th of April in Paris.






Prompt: “Paint a beautiful Gustave Caillebotte-inspired kitchen scene_ a bowl brimming with golden roasted cauliflower and chickpeas, bathed in creamy tahini”

title: Roasted Cauliflower and Chickpea Salad
text:
Ingredients

2 heads cauliflower, cut into small florets
2 cans chickpeas, drained and rinsed
2 tsp ground cumin
2 tsp ground coriander
1 tsp smoked paprika
1/2 tsp cayenne pepper
6 tbsp olive oil
Salt and pepper
1/2 cup tahini
4 tbsp lemon juice
2 garlic cloves, minced
1/2 cup water
Mixed greens, for serving

title: Roasted Cauliflower and Chickpea Salad
text:
Instructions

Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C).
In a large bowl, toss the cauliflower florets and chickpeas with cumin, coriander, smoked paprika, cayenne pepper, 4 tablespoons of olive oil, salt, and pepper until evenly coated.
Spread the cauliflower and chickpeas on two baking sheets lined with parchment paper and roast for 25 to 30 minutes or until golden and tender.
While the cauliflower and chickpeas are roasting, whisk together the tahini, lemon juice, garlic, remaining 2 tablespoons of olive oil, water, and salt in a small bowl until smooth.
Once the cauliflower and chickpeas are done roasting, let them cool for a few minutes.
In a large bowl, toss the roasted cauliflower and chickpeas with the tahini dressing until evenly coated.
Serve the salad on a bed of mixed greens.

Enjoy your Roasted Cauliflower and Chickpea Salad!

title: Salmon with Green Pea Sauce and Charred Broccoli
section: Starter: Salmon with Green Pea Sauce and Charred Broccoli
text:
Starter: Salmon with Green Pea Sauce and Charred Broccoli
Ingredients: - 6 salmon fillets (about 150g each, skin on)

400g frozen green peas, thawed
handful of mint, washed
200ml heavy cream
1 small garlic clove, crushed
Zest and juice of 1 lemon
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
500g broccoli, cut into florets
2 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp chopped fresh dill for garnish

Instructions: 1. Preheat the oven to 180°C (350°F).

Season the salmon fillets with salt and pepper. Place them on a baking tray, skin side down, and roast for 12-15 minutes, or until cooked to your desired level.
In the meantime, prepare the green pea sauce. In a blender, combine the peas, heavy cream, garlic, lemon zest, and juice. Blend until smooth, then season with salt and pepper to taste. If the sauce is too thick, add a splash of water to thin it out.
In a large bowl, toss the broccoli florets with olive oil, salt, and pepper. Heat a large grill pan or skillet over medium-high heat. Cook the broccoli, turning occasionally, until charred and tender, about 5-7 minutes.
To serve, spoon some green pea sauce onto each plate, top with a salmon fillet, and arrange the charred broccoli alongside. Garnish with fresh dill.

title: Chicken and parmesan soup with pappardelle
text:
Recipe for a sick Kathy, based on this recipe.






Prompt: “Using the contrast and realism found in Johannes Vermeer’s paintings, create a vibrant still life image, showcasing the ‘Chicken and Parmesan Soup with Pappardelle’. Illuminate the scene with warm, soft light akin to Vermeer’s ‘The Milkmaid’, emphasizing the rich texture of the soup, the steam rising from the bowl”

title: Chicken and parmesan soup with pappardelle
text:
Info
Prep 20 min Cook 1 hr 10 min Serves 4

title: Chicken and parmesan soup with pappardelle
text:
Ingredients

1.4 kg of chicken pieces (such as thighs or breasts)
1 whole head garlic, halved, plus 4 cloves, peeled and crushed
1 onion, cut into 4 wedges
Salt and black pepper
2 tbsp olive oil
2 carrots, peeled and cut into roughly 15mm cubes (220g net weight)
3 sticks celery, cut at an angle into roughly 1cm-thick slices (200g net weight)
3 bay leaves
1½ tbsp thyme leaves, finely chopped
60g parmesan, finely grated, plus 1 small piece of rind
5 plum tomatoes, coarsely grated and skins discarded (320g)
2 tsp tomato paste
180g dried pappardelle nests
15g basil leaves, finely shredded
1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
500ml beer of your choice
1.5 litres of water (or chicken stock if you prefer)

title: Chicken and parmesan soup with pappardelle
text:
Instructions

Season chicken pieces with salt and black pepper.
Put the olive oil in a large pan and set over medium-high heat. Add chicken pieces to the pan and saute until browned on all sides. Remove the chicken pieces and set aside.
In the same pan, saute the garlic, onion, carrots and celery for about 4 minutes until they start to soften.
Return the chicken pieces to the pan, add the bay leaves, thyme, parmesan rind, the beer, water (or chicken stock), and bring to a simmer. Cover and cook for 40-50 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through.
Remove the chicken pieces and once cool enough to handle, shred the meat; discard the skin and bones.
Add the crushed garlic, tomatoes, and tomato paste to the pan. Cook for three minutes, until the tomatoes cook down slightly. If using water, add 1.5 litres of hot water, salt, and a generous grind of pepper. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat to medium and cook for 15 minutes, or until the vegetables have softened.
Ladle out 400g of the soup, about 50/50 liquid to solids (avoid the bay and rind), transfer to a blender and blitz smooth. Stir back into the soup pan and turn up the heat to medium-high.
Add the pasta, shredded chicken and a good grind of pepper, and cook for 15 minutes, or until the pasta is al dente. Discard the bay leaves and parmesan rind.
Divide the soup between four bowls, top with the basil, chilli, a good grind of pepper and a sprinkling of grated parmesan, and serve with extra parmesan alongside.

This should give you a similar flavor profile to the original recipe, but with a hint of beer flavor from the added beer in the cooking process.

title: Apple and Rhubarb Jam Tartlets with Custard Filling
text:
I need help making a recipe for desert for this evening. We have some lovely tart apples, lots of eggs, some rhubarb jam, and can also go shopping for more ingredients.






Prompt: “Using the contrast and realism found in Johannes Vermeer’s paintings, create a vibrant still life image, showcasing the ‘Chicken and Parmesan Soup with Pappardelle’. Illuminate the scene with warm, soft light akin to Vermeer’s ‘The Milkmaid’, emphasizing the rich texture of the soup, the steam rising from the bowl”





Ingredients:

For the custard filling:

1 cup whole milk
1/2 vanilla bean (or 1 tsp vanilla extract)
3 egg yolks
1/4 cup granulated sugar
1 tbsp cornstarch
1 tbsp unsalted butter



For the topping:

Tart apples (sliced thinly)
Coconut syrup for glazing




Instructions:

Custard Filling:

In a saucepan, heat the milk and vanilla bean (scraped seeds and pod) until just boiling. Remove from heat and discard the pod (if using).
In a separate bowl, whisk together the egg yolks, sugar, and cornstarch until pale and thick.
Slowly pour the hot milk into the egg mixture while whisking constantly.
Pour the mixture back into the saucepan and cook over medium heat, whisking constantly until thickened. This should take around 3-5 minutes.
Remove from heat, stir in the butter until melted, and transfer the custard to a bowl. Cover with plastic wrap, pressing it directly onto the surface to prevent a skin from forming. Let cool to room temperature.



Assembly:

Fill each pre-made tartlet base with the custard filling, about 3/4 full.
Arrange the thinly sliced apples on top in a decorative manner.
If you have an oven-safe tartlet base, you can optionally place them under a broiler/grill for a few minutes to lightly caramelize the apples. Watch closely to ensure they don’t burn.
Drizzle or brush the coconut syrup over the apples for a glossy and flavorful finish.
Allow the tartlets to set a bit in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes to 1 hour.

Serve and enjoy! The combination of the rich custard, tart apples, and sweet coconut syrup should be delightful.

title: Champagne Sports Menu Planning
text:
Excited to be going to the Drakensberg with some special friends this weekend!
Recipes drawn from the best meals that I have enjoyed at Champagne Sports with family, as well as tasty restaurants in Cape Town and Copenhagen.








Friday Lunch: Deconstructed “Club Kloof” Platter
This is not so much a recipe as an assembly. Slow-roast the tomatoes until they are sweet and jammy. The capers are fried until they burst open like salty, crispy flowers.



Ingredients
For the Confit Tomatoes:

800g cherry tomatoes
4 cloves of garlic, peeled and smashed
4 sprigs of thyme
120ml extra virgin olive oil
1 tsp light brown sugar
Salt and black pepper

For the Crispy Capers:

4 tbsp capers in brine, drained
100ml sunflower oil




For Assembly:

1 large ball of fresh burrata or fior di latte
A generous handful of fresh basil leaves
High-quality sourdough or ciabatta
Gluten-free crackers
Your best extra virgin olive oil, for drizzling









Note



For Ineke: The burrata is the only conflict here. To supplement, provide a bowl of good quality hummus (seasoned with lemon, salt, and chilli) as a creamy, plant-based alternative for her.



Method

For the confit tomatoes (Prep Ahead): Preheat your oven to 150°C (130°C fan). Place the tomatoes in a snug-fitting baking dish. Tuck the smashed garlic cloves and thyme sprigs in amongst them. Drizzle generously with the olive oil, sprinkle over the sugar, a good pinch of salt, and a few grinds of black pepper. Toss gently. Roast for 1.5–2 hours, until the tomatoes are softened, slightly shrivelled, and intensely flavourful. Let them cool completely in their oil. This can be done up to three days in advance and stored in a sealed jar in the fridge.
For the crispy capers (Prep Ahead): Pat the drained capers completely dry with a paper towel—this is crucial for crisping and preventing oil splatters. Heat the sunflower oil in a small saucepan over a medium-high heat. Test the oil with one caper; it should sizzle immediately. Carefully add the rest of the capers and fry for 2–3 minutes, until they have ‘bloomed’ and look crisp. Remove with a slotted spoon to a paper towel-lined plate. They will crisp up further as they cool. Store in an airtight container.
To assemble: Let the burrata come to room temperature for 20 minutes for the best flavour and texture. Place it on a platter and gently tear it open. Spoon the confit tomatoes and their glorious oil all around it. Scatter with the fresh basil leaves and, finally, the crispy capers. Serve with the bread and crackers on the side.





Friday Dinner: Spatchcock Chicken with Potatoes in its Drippings
There are few things in life as comforting as a roast chicken.






Note



Adapting for Ineke: This meal requires a parallel main course. You will roast Ineke’s potatoes on a separate tray with olive oil and provide a beautiful piece of pan-seared fish instead of chicken. A bright salsa verde will replace the chicken gravy.





Ingredients

1 large free-range chicken (around 1.6kg)
700g baby potatoes, scrubbed
2 lemons
1 whole bulb of garlic, halved crossways
4 sprigs of thyme, plus extra for potatoes

For the Herb Butter:

80g unsalted butter, at room temperature
4 cloves garlic, crushed
1 tbsp thyme leaves, finely chopped
Zest of 1 lemon
1 tsp salt
½ tsp black pepper

For Ineke’s Main:

1 large fillet of fish salmon
1 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for potatoes
1 clove garlic, crushed
A few sprigs of thyme




For the Greens:

400g Tenderstem broccoli or green beans
1 tbsp olive oil
1 clove garlic, thinly sliced

For the Gravy:

1 tbsp cornflour
250ml chicken stock or water

For the Salsa Verde (for fish):

1 large bunch of flat-leaf parsley
2 tbsp capers, drained
1 clove garlic
Juice of ½ a lemon
4 tbsp extra virgin olive oil




Method

Prepare the chicken (On the Day): Preheat your oven to 200°C (180°C fan). First, make the herb butter by mixing all its ingredients in a small bowl.
Place the chicken breast-side down on a board. Using sturdy kitchen shears, cut along both sides of the backbone to remove it. Flip the chicken over and press down firmly on the breastbone to flatten it. Pat the chicken dry all over with paper towels.
Gently loosen the skin over the breasts and thighs and push half of the herb butter underneath. Rub the remaining butter all over the outside of the chicken. Season generously.
Prepare the potatoes: Cut any larger potatoes in half and place them in a pot of cold salted water. Bring to the boil and cook for 10 minutes until slightly tender. Drain well and shake the colander to rough up their edges.
Roast: Tip the par-boiled potatoes into a large roasting tin. Add the halved garlic bulb and extra thyme sprigs. Drizzle with a little olive oil. Place a wire rack over the potatoes and place the spatchcocked chicken on top. Squeeze the juice of one lemon over the chicken. Roast for 50–60 minutes, or until the juices run clear when the thickest part of the thigh is pierced.


For Ineke, toss her portion of potatoes on a separate, smaller baking tray with a generous drizzle of olive oil, a few smashed garlic cloves, and thyme.


Rest and finish: Remove the chicken to a board to rest for 15 minutes. You can place the potatoes back in the oven to crisp up further if needed. While the chicken rests, sauté your greens with the sliced garlic until tender-crisp.
For the gravy: Spoon off most of the fat from the roasting tin. Place the tin over a medium heat. Mix the cornflour with a little cold water to make a slurry, then whisk it into the tin with the chicken stock, scraping up all the caramelised bits from the bottom. Simmer for a few minutes until thickened.

For the salsa verde, blitz all the ingredients in a food processor until you have a rough sauce. Season to taste.

Carve the chicken and serve with the incredible potatoes, greens, and the pan gravy.





Saturday Lunch: Mushroom Pâté & Seed Tartlets on Puff Pastry
This starter is an exercise in umami. The seeds on top add a nice crunch.



Ingredients

1 sheet of all-butter puff pastry, thawed
1 egg, beaten
1 tbsp sunflower seeds (or a mix of seeds)

For the Mushroom Pâté:

2 tbsp olive oil
500g mixed mushrooms (like portabellini and exotic), roughly chopped
2 shallots or 1 small onion, finely chopped
2 cloves garlic, crushed
1 tbsp thyme leaves
1 tsp soy sauce
Salt and freshly ground black pepper







Method

Make the mushroom pâté (Prep Ahead): Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan over a medium-high heat. Add the shallots and cook for 5 minutes until soft. Add the chopped mushrooms and cook, stirring occasionally, for 10–15 minutes. The mushrooms will first release a lot of water; continue cooking until all the water has evaporated and the mushrooms start to caramelise and turn golden brown.
Add the garlic and thyme and cook for another minute until fragrant. Add the soy sauce and a generous amount of salt and pepper. Stir well.
Transfer the mushroom mixture to a food processor. Pulse a few times until you have a coarse, spreadable pâté. You don’t want a perfectly smooth puree. Let it cool completely. This can be stored in the fridge for up to 3 days.
Assemble and bake (On the Day): Preheat your oven to 200°C (180°C fan). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Unroll the puff pastry sheet. You can either cut it into small squares or rounds for individual tartlets, or leave it whole for a larger tart to slice. Place the pastry on the prepared baking sheet.
Spread the cooled mushroom pâté over the pastry, leaving a 1cm border around the edge.
Brush the border with the beaten egg. Sprinkle the sunflower seeds over the mushroom pâté.
Bake for 15–20 minutes, until the pastry is puffed up, deeply golden, and crisp. Serve warm.





Sunday Lunch Starter: Tempura Cauliflower with Tahini & Chilli Crunch
Inspired by a meal at Kima in CPH.



Ingredients

1 head of cauliflower, broken into bite-sized florets
1 litre sunflower oil, for frying

For the Tempura Batter:

100g plain flour (or GF flour mix)
50g cornflour
½ tsp salt
200ml ice-cold sparkling water

For the Tahini Sauce & Garnish:

3 tbsp tahini
1 clove garlic, crushed
Juice of ½ a lemon
2–3 tbsp water, to thin
Salt
Chilli Crunch, to serve
Handful of fresh coriander or parsley, chopped







Method

Make the tahini sauce (Prep Ahead): In a small bowl, whisk together the tahini, crushed garlic, and lemon juice. It will seize up and become thick—this is normal. Gradually whisk in the cold water, one tablespoon at a time, until you have a smooth, pourable sauce the consistency of single cream. Season with salt.
Prepare for frying (On the Day): Heat the sunflower oil in a large, deep saucepan to 180°C. If you don’t have a thermometer, a small drop of batter should sizzle and turn golden in about 30 seconds.
Make the batter: Just before you are ready to fry, whisk the flour, cornflour, and salt together in a bowl. Gently pour in the ice-cold sparkling water and whisk very lightly. A few lumps are perfectly fine; over-mixing will make the batter heavy.
Fry the cauliflower: Working in batches, dip the cauliflower florets into the batter, letting any excess drip off. Carefully place them in the hot oil. Fry for 3–4 minutes, turning occasionally, until light golden and very crisp. Do not overcrowd the pan.
Remove the fried florets with a slotted spoon to a wire rack to drain. Sprinkle immediately with a little salt.
To serve: Arrange the hot tempura cauliflower on a platter. Drizzle generously with the tahini sauce, spoon over some of the chilli crunch, and finish with a scattering of fresh herbs. Serve immediately.





Sunday Lunch Main: Fragrant Thai Curry with Pan-Seared Halibut
Based on Kathy’s birthday meal at the Pot Luck Club.



Ingredients

2 x 180g halibut fillets, skin on
200g raw, peeled prawns
1 tbsp sunflower oil
Steamed jasmine rice, to serve

For the Curry Sauce:

1 tbsp coconut or sunflower oil
2 cloves garlic, finely grated
2cm piece of ginger, finely grated
3-4 tbsp red Thai curry paste
400ml can full-fat coconut milk
200ml vegetable or chicken stock
1 tsp brown sugar
Juice of 1 lime

To Finish:

A large handful of fresh coriander, roughly chopped
A few fresh basil leaves (Thai basil if you can find it)
1 fresh red chilli, thinly sliced (optional)
Lime wedges, to serve







Method

Start the jasmine rice according to packet instructions so it is ready when the curry is.
Build the curry base: Heat the coconut oil in a saucepan or wok over a medium heat. Add the grated garlic and ginger and fry for a minute until fragrant. Add the curry paste and cook for another 2 minutes, stirring, until it darkens and becomes very aromatic.
Pour in the coconut milk and stock, whisking to combine with the paste. Bring to a gentle simmer, then add the brown sugar. Let it simmer gently for 10 minutes for the flavours to meld.
Cook the seafood: While the sauce simmers, prepare the halibut. Pat the skin completely dry with a paper towel and season the fillets with salt. Heat the sunflower oil in a non-stick frying pan over a medium-high heat. Place the halibut skin-side down and press gently with a spatula for 30 seconds to ensure it’s flat against the pan. Cook for 3–4 minutes, until the skin is golden and very crisp. Flip and cook for another 1–2 minutes, depending on the thickness, until just cooked through. Remove from the pan and set aside.
Finish the sauce: Add the raw prawns to the simmering curry sauce and cook for just 2–3 minutes, until they turn pink and opaque. Stir in the fresh lime juice.
To serve: Ladle the jasmine rice into shallow bowls. Spoon the fragrant curry and prawns over the rice. Gently place a piece of crispy-skinned halibut on top of each bowl. Garnish generously with the fresh coriander, basil, and sliced chilli. Serve immediately with extra lime wedges on the side.

1 large free-range chicken (around 1.6kg)
700g baby potatoes, scrubbed
2 lemons
1 whole bulb of garlic, halved crossways
4 sprigs of thyme, plus extra for potatoes

For the Herb Butter:

80g unsalted butter, at room temperature
4 cloves garlic, crushed
1 tbsp thyme leaves, finely chopped
Zest of 1 lemon
1 tsp salt
½ tsp black pepper

For Ineke’s Main:

1 large fillet of fish salmon
1 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for potatoes
1 clove garlic, crushed
A few sprigs of thyme




For the Greens:

400g Tenderstem broccoli or green beans
1 tbsp olive oil
1 clove garlic, thinly sliced

For the Gravy:

1 tbsp cornflour
250ml chicken stock or water

For the Salsa Verde (for fish):

1 large bunch of flat-leaf parsley
2 tbsp capers, drained
1 clove garlic
Juice of ½ a lemon
4 tbsp extra virgin olive oil






Prepare the chicken (On the Day): Preheat your oven to 200°C (180°C fan). First, make the herb butter by mixing all its ingredients in a small bowl.
Place the chicken breast-side down on a board. Using sturdy kitchen shears, cut along both sides of the backbone to remove it. Flip the chicken over and press down firmly on the breastbone to flatten it. Pat the chicken dry all over with paper towels.
Gently loosen the skin over the breasts and thighs and push half of the herb butter underneath. Rub the remaining butter all over the outside of the chicken. Season generously.
Prepare the potatoes: Cut any larger potatoes in half and place them in a pot of cold salted water. Bring to the boil and cook for 10 minutes until slightly tender. Drain well and shake the colander to rough up their edges.
Roast: Tip the par-boiled potatoes into a large roasting tin. Add the halved garlic bulb and extra thyme sprigs. Drizzle with a little olive oil. Place a wire rack over the potatoes and place the spatchcocked chicken on top. Squeeze the juice of one lemon over the chicken. Roast for 50–60 minutes, or until the juices run clear when the thickest part of the thigh is pierced.


For Ineke, toss her portion of potatoes on a separate, smaller baking tray with a generous drizzle of olive oil, a few smashed garlic cloves, and thyme.


Rest and finish: Remove the chicken to a board to rest for 15 minutes. You can place the potatoes back in the oven to crisp up further if needed. While the chicken rests, sauté your greens with the sliced garlic until tender-crisp.
For the gravy: Spoon off most of the fat from the roasting tin. Place the tin over a medium heat. Mix the cornflour with a little cold water to make a slurry, then whisk it into the tin with the chicken stock, scraping up all the caramelised bits from the bottom. Simmer for a few minutes until thickened.

For the salsa verde, blitz all the ingredients in a food processor until you have a rough sauce. Season to taste.

Carve the chicken and serve with the incredible potatoes, greens, and the pan gravy.






This starter is an exercise in umami. The seeds on top add a nice crunch.





1 sheet of all-butter puff pastry, thawed
1 egg, beaten
1 tbsp sunflower seeds (or a mix of seeds)

For the Mushroom Pâté:

2 tbsp olive oil
500g mixed mushrooms (like portabellini and exotic), roughly chopped
2 shallots or 1 small onion, finely chopped
2 cloves garlic, crushed
1 tbsp thyme leaves
1 tsp soy sauce
Salt and freshly ground black pepper









Make the mushroom pâté (Prep Ahead): Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan over a medium-high heat. Add the shallots and cook for 5 minutes until soft. Add the chopped mushrooms and cook, stirring occasionally, for 10–15 minutes. The mushrooms will first release a lot of water; continue cooking until all the water has evaporated and the mushrooms start to caramelise and turn golden brown.
Add the garlic and thyme and cook for another minute until fragrant. Add the soy sauce and a generous amount of salt and pepper. Stir well.
Transfer the mushroom mixture to a food processor. Pulse a few times until you have a coarse, spreadable pâté. You don’t want a perfectly smooth puree. Let it cool completely. This can be stored in the fridge for up to 3 days.
Assemble and bake (On the Day): Preheat your oven to 200°C (180°C fan). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Unroll the puff pastry sheet. You can either cut it into small squares or rounds for individual tartlets, or leave it whole for a larger tart to slice. Place the pastry on the prepared baking sheet.
Spread the cooled mushroom pâté over the pastry, leaving a 1cm border around the edge.
Brush the border with the beaten egg. Sprinkle the sunflower seeds over the mushroom pâté.
Bake for 15–20 minutes, until the pastry is puffed up, deeply golden, and crisp. Serve warm.






Inspired by a meal at Kima in CPH.





1 head of cauliflower, broken into bite-sized florets
1 litre sunflower oil, for frying

For the Tempura Batter:

100g plain flour (or GF flour mix)
50g cornflour
½ tsp salt
200ml ice-cold sparkling water

For the Tahini Sauce & Garnish:

3 tbsp tahini
1 clove garlic, crushed
Juice of ½ a lemon
2–3 tbsp water, to thin
Salt
Chilli Crunch, to serve
Handful of fresh coriander or parsley, chopped









Make the tahini sauce (Prep Ahead): In a small bowl, whisk together the tahini, crushed garlic, and lemon juice. It will seize up and become thick—this is normal. Gradually whisk in the cold water, one tablespoon at a time, until you have a smooth, pourable sauce the consistency of single cream. Season with salt.
Prepare for frying (On the Day): Heat the sunflower oil in a large, deep saucepan to 180°C. If you don’t have a thermometer, a small drop of batter should sizzle and turn golden in about 30 seconds.
Make the batter: Just before you are ready to fry, whisk the flour, cornflour, and salt together in a bowl. Gently pour in the ice-cold sparkling water and whisk very lightly. A few lumps are perfectly fine; over-mixing will make the batter heavy.
Fry the cauliflower: Working in batches, dip the cauliflower florets into the batter, letting any excess drip off. Carefully place them in the hot oil. Fry for 3–4 minutes, turning occasionally, until light golden and very crisp. Do not overcrowd the pan.
Remove the fried florets with a slotted spoon to a wire rack to drain. Sprinkle immediately with a little salt.
To serve: Arrange the hot tempura cauliflower on a platter. Drizzle generously with the tahini sauce, spoon over some of the chilli crunch, and finish with a scattering of fresh herbs. Serve immediately.






Based on Kathy’s birthday meal at the Pot Luck Club.





2 x 180g halibut fillets, skin on
200g raw, peeled prawns
1 tbsp sunflower oil
Steamed jasmine rice, to serve

For the Curry Sauce:

1 tbsp coconut or sunflower oil
2 cloves garlic, finely grated
2cm piece of ginger, finely grated
3-4 tbsp red Thai curry paste
400ml can full-fat coconut milk
200ml vegetable or chicken stock
1 tsp brown sugar
Juice of 1 lime

To Finish:

A large handful of fresh coriander, roughly chopped
A few fresh basil leaves (Thai basil if you can find it)
1 fresh red chilli, thinly sliced (optional)
Lime wedges, to serve









Start the jasmine rice according to packet instructions so it is ready when the curry is.
Build the curry base: Heat the coconut oil in a saucepan or wok over a medium heat. Add the grated garlic and ginger and fry for a minute until fragrant. Add the curry paste and cook for another 2 minutes, stirring, until it darkens and becomes very aromatic.
Pour in the coconut milk and stock, whisking to combine with the paste. Bring to a gentle simmer, then add the brown sugar. Let it simmer gently for 10 minutes for the flavours to meld.
Cook the seafood: While the sauce simmers, prepare the halibut. Pat the skin completely dry with a paper towel and season the fillets with salt. Heat the sunflower oil in a non-stick frying pan over a medium-high heat. Place the halibut skin-side down and press gently with a spatula for 30 seconds to ensure it’s flat against the pan. Cook for 3–4 minutes, until the skin is golden and very crisp. Flip and cook for another 1–2 minutes, depending on the thickness, until just cooked through. Remove from the pan and set aside.
Finish the sauce: Add the raw prawns to the simmering curry sauce and cook for just 2–3 minutes, until they turn pink and opaque. Stir in the fresh lime juice.
To serve: Ladle the jasmine rice into shallow bowls. Spoon the fragrant curry and prawns over the rice. Gently place a piece of crispy-skinned halibut on top of each bowl. Garnish generously with the fresh coriander, basil, and sliced chilli. Serve immediately with extra lime wedges on the side.
